newsitem.title: ISRAEL: PLO officials say summit imminent.
newsitem.headline: PLO officials say summit imminent.

text.p: PLO officials said Palestinian President Yasser Arafat would meet Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu for the first time on Wednesday. But Netanyahu's spokesman said no meeting had been set.

Ahmed Abdel-Rahman, general secretary of the Palestinian Authority, told Reuters: "The meeting will take place soon." Chief PLO negotiator Mahmoud Abbas, asked when a summit would be held, advised reporters: "Go to Erez," the Israeli-Gaza crossing point where a summit could take place.
A spokesman for Netanyahu said no meeting had been set. He said any announcement would come from the prime minister's office.
Israeli and Palestinian negotiators have been struggling over the past week to find a formula that would enable the men to meet and for full-fledged peace talks to resume.
Netanyahu, elected in May on a pledge not to swap occupied Arab land for peace, had said originally he preferred not to meet Arafat but softened his position in recent days.
Palestinians have been pressing for a summit and resumed talks to tackle the issue of Israel's long-delayed troop redeployment from the West Bank town of Hebron.
